short_answer: Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the lung volume at the end of passive expiration. It reflects the equilibrium between inward elastic recoil of the lungs and outward recoil of the chest wall. Changes in compliance, posture, or diaphragmatic tone can shift FRC.

references.title: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th ed.

short_answer: Apoptosis is an organised, energy-dependent process of cell death without inflammation. It features cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and DNA fragmentation into nucleosomal ladders. Necrosis, in contrast, involves loss of membrane integrity and an inflammatory response.

short_answer: The elimination half-life (t½) is determined by the drug’s volume of distribution and clearance: t½ = 0.693 × Vd / CL. A large Vd or reduced clearance prolongs half-life. Understanding this guides dosing intervals and steady-state estimation.

short_answer: A spiral fracture of the humeral shaft endangers the radial nerve, which traverses the spiral groove posteriorly with the profunda brachii artery. Injury results in wrist-drop and sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand.
